Name: Pattern Recognition - IND
Text: Okay, lets tackle this problem step by step. First, I need to understand the two parts: the normative rules (strict) and the desiderata (recommended). The user provided an event log with three cases and wants me to identify violations and suboptimal behaviors. Starting with Part 1, the normative constraints. The sequence must be Application Received Credit Check Risk Assessment Loan Decision Inform Applicant [Finalize Documentation if approved] Close Case. Also, certain ordering rules must be followed. Lets check each case.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 1: Looking at the activities in order. They received the application, did credit check, risk assessment, approved, informed, finalized docs, closed. Everything seems to follow the sequence. No violations here.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 2: Application received, then Risk Assessment before Credit Check. Thats a clear violation because Credit Check must come before Risk Assessment. Also, after rejection, they finalized documentation which is not allowed. So two violations here: wrong order and finalizing after rejection.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 3: The activities are in the correct order. Application received, credit check (though delayed), risk assessment, approved, informed (late), finalized, closed. The order is correct. But theres no Follow-up Call, which is a desideratum. The timing of Credit Check and informing the applicant are late but thats only a recommendation violation.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - IND
Text: Now for Part 2, desiderata. Case 1: All timings seem within 24 hours for Credit Check and 48 hours for informing. They might have done a Follow-up Call? The log doesnt mention it, but since its not in the events, maybe they didnt. But since its a recommendation, its just suboptimal.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - IND
Text: Case 2: Even though they had violations in normative rules, their timing might be okay? But since they rejected, maybe timing isnt relevant here. But the main issue is the normative violations.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 3: Credit Check happened more than 24 hours after application (from 12th to 14th), and informing took over 48 hours from decision (14th to 16th). Also, no Follow-up Call. These are all desideratum violations.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - IND
Text: Possible justifications: For Case 2s Finalize Documentation after rejection, maybe an error in logging or an exception case where documentation was needed for record-keeping despite rejection. But according to rules, its not allowed. For Case 3s delays, maybe high volume of applications caused delays, which is understandable but not ideal.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: So summarizing: Normative violations: Only Case 2. Desideratum issues: Cases 1 (maybe no follow-up), 3 (delays and no follow-up).
